questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding amenorrhoea?

options.A: MRKH syndrome is associated with secondary amenorrhoea
options.B: Primary amenorrhoea is seen in Turner syndrome
options.C: Primary amenorrhea is absence of menarche by 13 years
options.D: Secondary amenorrhea is absence of menses for 6 months

questions.question: While evaluating a patient with secondary amenorrhoea, you administer her estrogen andprogesterone. However, withdrawal bleeding is not seen. What is the likely site of lesionhere?
questions.explanation: The absence of withdrawal bleeding after the estrogen-progesterone challenge test points towardsa local endometrial lesion.Estrogen-progesterone challenge test is indicated as an investigation in case of secondaryamenorrhea. It depends on estrogen-primed endometrium being present in the uterus.Procedure:• Ethinyl estradiol 0.02 mg or conjugated equine estrogen 1.25 mg is to be taken daily for 25 days.Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily is added from day 15–25.••Alternately, one course of oral contraceptive pill is given and to observe whether withdrawalbleeding occurs or not.Results:• If there is no bleeding, a local endometrial lesion is present such as uterine synechiae. This is tobe confirmed by HSG or hysteroscopy.• If withdrawal bleeding occurs, the endometrium is responsive but the endogenous estrogenproduction is inadequate. Hence, the defect lies in the ovary, hypothalamus, or pituitary.560

questions.question: The risk of Asherman syndrome is highest if D&C is done for
questions.explanation: The risk of developing Asherman syndrome is the highest if D&C is done for postpartumhemorrhage.This is because the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier. Hence, a greater area of the uterinewall is curetted. This increases the risk of developing Asherman syndrome.Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas ofthe endometrium. The treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding oligomenorrhea?

options.C: Menstruation occurring at an interval of more than 30 days

questions.explanation: Oligomenorrhoea can progress to develop into amenorrhoea.Oligomenorrhoea means infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring atintervals of more than 38 days.

questions.question: A patient with uterine fibroids complains of frequent menstruation with an average cycleduration of 19-21 days. What is this menstrual irregularity called?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of polymenorrhoea, also known as epimenorrhea. It refersto frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less.The definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities are:Amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menstruation.Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) thatoccur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles, but having scanty episodes of bleeding.Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL inamount) and/or increased duration of flow (>8 days).Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes ofbleeding.Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed andfrequent intervals.Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 38 days.Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding menorrhagia?

options.A: Heavy and regularly timed episodes of bleeding
options.C: Amount of bleeding greater than 50 ml
options.D: Duration of bleeding greater than 5 days

questions.explanation: 561Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding.Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80mL) and/or duration of flow (>8 days). Nowadays, menorrhagia has been replaced by the termheavy menstrual bleeding. This is defined as greater than 80 mL per cycle, which will result inanemia if recurrentInvestigations done in case of menorrhagia:•Complete blood count (CBC) - to rule out anemia and thrombocytopenia.Coagulation studies are ordered only in case of clinical suspicion and correlation with CBC• Sonohysterography/Hysteroscopy to diagnose endometrial polyps and fibroids-• Endometrial biopsy - in case of suspected endometrial hyperplasia• Transvaginal ultrasound - supplements biopsy

questions.question: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months.The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal managementhas been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsiveto non-hormonal therapy.Menorrhagia/heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding,>80mL of blood loss, or >8 days of bleeding per menstrual period. It can be acute (<6months) or chronic (>6 months).It is managed as follows:• Medical first line of treatment.• NSAIDS-• Tranexamic acid⚫ OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails•• Mirena IUCD• GnRH agonists• Blood transfusion, if required•••Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc (option B)• Uterine artery embolization (option A)• Uterine tamponade• Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail (option D)

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of menometrorrhagia?
questions.explanation: Menometrorrhagia refers to menstrual bleeding at frequent intervals.562Menometrorrhagia means excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed andfrequent intervals. It can be caused by cervical cancer and granulosa cell tumors.

questions.question: A patient who had undergone a dilatation and curettage procedure comes to the clinic 6months later for a follow-up visit. She informs you that since the procedure, she has hadscanty blood loss during menses which only lasts for 1-2 days. What is this pattern of bleedingcalled?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the pattern of bleeding is called hypomenorrhea. Hypomenorrheaalong with a prior history of dilatation and curettage are suggestive of partial Asherman'ssyndrome.Hypomenorrhoea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding. It can be seen in:• Partial Asherman's syndrome - uterine synechiae, causing scarring• Oral contraceptive use• Perimenopausal age group

questions.question: A 36-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of occasional bleedingPV between her usual menstrual cycles. Which of the following is true about her condition?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of intermenstrual bleeding, also known as metrorrhagia.Usually, this is scanty, and not excessive.Intermenstrual bleeding or metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleedingsuperimposed on normal cyclical bleeding. It can be caused by:• Ovulation (physiological)• Polyps•Cervical cancer• Lower genital tract infections etc.

questions.question: A young girl with McCune-Albright syndrome is noted to have precocious menstruation. Thiscondition is defined as the occurrence of menstruation at
questions.explanation: Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics beforethe age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years.McCune Albright syndrome is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (andprecocious menstruation), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to recurrent fractures. Theimage given below shows cafe-au-lait spots.563

questions.question: 556A 45-year-old woman presents with profuse, painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of6-8 weeks of amenorrhea and her UPT is negative. On ultrasound, endometrial thickness is21mm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.Metropathia hemorrhagica is a form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding. It is characterizedby continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week periodof amenorrhea. It is usually seen in the age group of 40-45 years. A history of menorrhagia may bepresent.On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:•Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm• Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as swiss cheese pattern•Absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands•• Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity•Corpus luteum is absent•One or both ovaries may contain a cystOption A: Senile endometritis occurs after menopause when the endometrium is thin andatrophic. It may be associated with accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity.Option B: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regularcycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow is present.Option D: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms ofmenorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

questions.question: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.explanation: 564The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands foriatrogenic causes.AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding,however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:• Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.• Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum.PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:•Polyp (AUB-P):•Endometrial polyps• Endocervical polyps• Adenomyosis (AUB-A)• Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:• Submucosal (SM)Other (O)• Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M)• Endometrial hyperplasia• Endometrial carcinoma•Coagulopathy (AUB-C)• von Willebrand's disease• Hemophilias• Ovarian causes (AUB-O)• PCOD•Hypothyroidism• Hyperprolactinemia.• Endometrial causes (AUB-E)•⚫ Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis• Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)•Intrauterine contraceptive devices• Anticoagulants• Tricyclic antidepressants• Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as• Arteriovenous malformations• Myometrial hypertrophy565

questions.question: A 28-year-old P1L1 woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and occasional spottingbetween cycles. What is the first investigation to be done for her?
questions.explanation: The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductiveage group is urine ẞ-hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy.In the reproductive age group, anovulatory uterine bleeding is encountered less often. Therefore,pregnancy must be excluded. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies,and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence these need to be ruled out by urineẞ-hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group.Other investigations to be done for AUB are:-• Pap smear to rule out cervical cancer and preinvasive lesions (CIN).• Transabdominal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs and lesions such as endometrialhyperplasia, polyps, fibroids, etc.• Transvaginal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs. It is done after evaluating ẞ-hCG. This ismore comfortable for a patient compared to a transabdominal ultrasound as it doesn't require afull bladder.

questions.question: A woman with AUB-E, who was unresponsive to medical management, underwent ahysteroscopic ablation. Which of the following is false about this procedure?
questions.explanation: Fertility is not preserved with ablative procedures, because the endometrium and superficialmyometrium are destroyed.In ablative procedures, the uterus is preserved, and hysterectomy is avoided. The endometriumalong with 2-3mm of superficial myometrium is destroyed.Various methods of endometrial ablation include:•Hysteroscopic endometrial ablation• Transcervical endometrial resection (TCRE) - now replaced by bipolar electrode calledVersapoint•Radiofrequency induced thermal ablation (RITEA)• Microwave ablation• NovaSure - impedance-controlled endometrial ablation• Bilateral uterine artery embolization• Uterine tamponade

questions.question: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated?
questions.explanation: Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) as itincreases the risk of ascending genital infection.D&C is a minor gynecological procedure of dilating the cervix and curetting the endometrialtissue from the uterine cavity. Diagnostic indications of D&C include AUB, secondary566amenorrhea to detect tubercular endometritis, postmenopausal bleeding to rule out endometrialcancer or hyperplasia, and infertility due to genital TB.Therapeutic indications of D&C include missed abortion, incomplete abortion, retainedproducts of conception, and endometrial polypectomy.Absolute contraindication of D&C includes Suspected/ desired pregnancy and lower genitaltract infection. However, D&C is performed in some cases with genital infections like septicabortion (where retained pieces of placenta act as a nidus and need to be removed) and pyometra(as there is cervical obstruction with superinfection of menstrual blood and cellular debris,D&C is appropriate to remove the obstruction as well as the source of infection)Complications of D&C include ascending infection, cervical tear with bleeding, incompetentos, uterine perforation, and ashermann syndrome.SCO MARROV

questions.question: A 31-year-old woman presented with acute abdominal pain and spotting. UPT was negative.On examination, she was tachycardic and afebrile. Guarding and abdominal tenderness waspresent. CT abdomen showed air in the uterine wall and pneumoperitoneum. Which of thefollowing is her condition most likely to be a complication of?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine perforation. In a non-pregnant uterus, uterineperforation is most likely to occur due to dilatation and curettage.In pregnancy and uterine malignancies, the uterus is soft. Hence, uterine perforation iscommon during surgeries.The etiology of uterine perforation is as follows:•Insertion of intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCD)- due to the lack of provider experience.•Spontaneous migration of IUCD within the myometrium• Dilatation and curettage (D&C)• Hysteroscopy - diagnostic (e.g, hysteroscopic biopsy) or therapeutic (adhesiolysis)• Laparoscopy567It can present with fever, acute abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and bleeding pv. Imagingreveals air within the uterine wall or pneumoperitoneum.The management is as follows:• Conservative management - Fundal injuries are managed conservatively, as the myometriumcontracts around the defect.•Surgical management:• Small defects can be repaired laparoscopically or hysteroscopically..Emergency laparotomy - as abdominal viscera may prolapse through the defect.• Hysterectomy - if the defect is large, and the patient has completed her family, hysterectomy isdone as last resort.

questions.question: An 18-year-old girl presents to you with cramping abdominal pain. It starts at the onset ofmenses and is more pronounced in the first two days. Which condition is she likely sufferingfrom?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of spasmodic dysmenorrhea. It presents with cramping painat the onset of menses which is more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation.Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation. It can be classified asfollows:A. Etiological classification:•Primary dysmenorrhoea - no identifiable pelvic pathology. Commonly occurs in the age group of18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.• Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhoea - is associated with pelvic pathologies such as fibroids,adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis.Unilateral dysmenorrhoea can occur in a rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus, IUCD users,and cervical stenosis.B. Clinical classification:• Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea:• Most prevalent•Cramping pain at the onset of menses, more pronounced on the first 2 days.⚫ Occurs due to myometrial contractions due to increased PGF2°• Common in adolescents and young women•Congestive dysmenorrhoea:•• Pelvic pain and pelvic discomfort occurs, a few days before menses begin•Occurs due to pelvic venous congestion•Seen in pelvic endometriosis, PID, fibroids, and IUCD users• Membranous dysmenorrhoea:• Least prevalent568• The endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation• The passage of the cast is associated with painful uterine cramps

questions.question: An increase in which of the following is spasmodic pain during dysmenorrhoea attributed to?
questions.explanation: Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions occuring due to increased PGF2°. This issecreted under the effect of progesterone.Progesterone is secreted after ovulation by the corpus luteum. Hence, in anovulatorycycles, menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of mood swings anddepression 10 days prior to her menses. This is associated with fatigue, breast tenderness,and bloating. Her symptoms resolve once menses begin. What is the treatment of choice inthis case?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Selectiveserotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine, sertraline, and paroxetine are thetreatment of choice for PMDD.DSM-5 defines premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) as the presence of at least five of theassociated symptoms most of the time during the premenstrual week. Symptoms improve withina few days after menses and are minimal in the postmenstrual period. These symptoms include:• Marked emotional lability• Marked irritability or anger• Marked depressive mood, self-deprecating thoughtsMarked anxiety• Decreased interest in activities• Difficulty in concentration• Lethargy• Appetite changes•Bloating•• Breast tenderness• Weight gain•Treatment of PMDD is as follows:Lifestyle changes such as - stress reduction, adequate sleep, and exercise, reduction in caffeineintake, smoking cessation• Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) - fluoxetine, paroxetine, sertraline•Evening primrose oil - to treat breast tenderness• Ovulation suppression - danazol, leuprolide, drospirenone• Other less proven methods - cognitive behavioral therapy, calcium supplements, etc.569Note: Premenstrual syndrome has no scientific definition. The constellation of symptoms is nowdefined under PMDD.570
